p.s: Further analysing the text by Peter Daszak, he used a specific and directed language and a lot of stylistic devices to convince the readers of his state of mind.
Firstly, one can divide the text into eight passages, where each one deals with a distingtdistinct topic.
Peter Daszakstartstarts his article ofoff, by shortly introducing the readers to the topic.
Since he is talking about pandemics and virus outbreaks, he makes sure to name examples, so the readers will know in which direction Daszak article goes.
He points out the HIV virus from the 1920s and also brings up the current Covid-19 pandemic (ll. 12-16).
Through these examples he can visualize his point of view and make it clear for the readers.
Peter Daszak also start his article with a very impactful short sentence, Every pandemic starts like this (l. 11).
This way he sounds very confident in his opinion and influences the readers as well.
Additionally Daszak uses inclusive language to appeal even more to his readers.
Throughout his text he refers to all humans as we.

For example we're entering a new pandemic era' (l. 19), ..., our new geological epoch, has changed everything (l. 29) or ... while we wait for vaccine, hundres o thousands of people have died, ... (ll. 38-39).
By doing this, Daszak makes sure to speak directly to his readers.
The author also blends in many negativlynegatively connotated words in these sentences to make the readers be aware of the seriousness of this problem and feel guilty about their actions.
For instance Daszak useuses words like pandemic era (l. 19) or dramitacally altered (l. 30).
These words are exageratingexaggerating, but make the readers feel guilt and directly affected by the outbreak of the global pandemic.
The author continues to name examples to prove his point.
He is of the opinion that humans get in contact with wildlife and wild animals too often nowdaysnowadays.
Humans get into a lot of contact with tropical rainforests that carry a large amount of viruses (ll. 20ff).
To underline his point he lists various examples and makes use of an accumulation.
For example he brings up that about 1.7 million virus can be found in animals in the rainforest which are also in most cases the cause for many outbreaks (l. 23).
Right after that he highlighthighlights that only 0.1% of the 1.7 million viruses have been described (l. 24), which furthermore empathizes the seriousness of his topic.
Later on in the secontsecond half of his text Peter Daszak describes how vaccines and other drugs cannot always be the solution to all those viruses and pandemics (l. 38ff.).
According to him we should not rely on vaccines because producing them takes a long time.
In between many people die, which means we need to prevent pandemics in other ways like Daszak says (ll. 40-41).
To support this argument he uses an anaphora by starting the sentences with the word we (ll. 42, 44, 46).
Here he creates hammering-in effects and also speaks to the readers directly.
As already mentioned he tries to make thereaders feel guilty about their actions that suposedlysupposedly caused the current pandemic.
In order to make the readesr feel less guilty he gives a lot of solutions on how to prevent future virus pandemics.
He says that we should stop overconsumption, wildlife exploitation and trading illegelyillegally at wildlife markets (l. 43ff.).
He is of the opinion that more pressure should be practiced on industries in order to achieve more sustainanabilitysustainability in our consumption behaviour (l. 46ff).
Lastly Peter Daszak ends his article with the sentence once we accepted that human activity is what let to this, we may finally be empowered to escape the pandemic era (ll. 55-56).
Only by working together as mankind we can get away from the new pandemic era Daszak describes.
Through his choisechoice of words he creates hope among the readers and letlets them think about their own opinion and to convince them even more of his opinion.
All in all it can be said that Peter Daszak uses numerous stylistic devices and directed language to convince the readers of his opinion.
He listed a lot of examples to prove his points.
The inclusive language helped involving the readers into the text and being able to relate to what Peter Daszak is saying.
The author made his point clear and informed about the seriousness of the new pandemic era and it'sits consequences.
